question: Question_07_(c)
statement:
The probability that a newly divided cell will divide again
\textbf{before} \emph{t} hours (where \emph{t} $\geq$ 0) is given by

\[F(t) = 1-e^{-t/12}\]

(c) What is the median division time?
sols:
The median \emph{t\textsubscript{med}} is defined as

\[F(t_\text{med}) = \frac12\]

Since \emph{F(t)} is given we can easily calculate that

\[\frac12 = F(t_\text{med}) = 1-e^{-t_\text{med}/12}, \quadÂ \text{i.e.} \quad e^{-t_\text{med}/12} = \frac12.\]

After cross multiplying we get $\displaystyle e^{t_\text{med}/12} = 2.$
Taking the logarithm \emph{ln(x)} on both sides yields the final answer

\[t_\text{med} = 12\ln(2).\]

\emph{Note: From the class notes you may remember that the median
waiting time is given by ln(2)/k. Here k=1/12, see part (a), so our
calculated answer agrees with the answer we expected.}
hints:
There is a direct relation between the median and the cumulative
function.
